findings.title: IDI - Immutable Declaration Improvement
findings.description: The contract declares state variables that are initialized once in the constructor and are not modified afterwards. Declaring these variables as immutable can save gas by allowing the Solidity compiler to make certain optimizations.

findings.title: PLPI - Potential Liquidity Provision Inadequacy
findings.description: The contract operates under the assumption that liquidity is consistently provided to the pair between the contract's token and the native currency. However, there is a possibility that liquidity is provided to a different pair.

findings.title: PVC - Price Volatility Concern
findings.description: The contract accumulates tokens from taxes to swap them for ETH, but if the variable `minimumTokensBeforeSwap` is set to a big number, it could lead to significant price volatility for the parties involved.

findings.title: RED - Redundant Event Declaration
findings.description: There are code segments that could be optimized. A segment may be optimized so that it becomes a smaller size, consumes less memory, executes more rapidly, or performs fewer operations. The following events are declared and not being used in the contract.

findings.title: RSW - Redundant Storage Writes
findings.description: The contract performs redundant storage writes when the provided parameter matches the current state of the variables, leading to unnecessary gas consumption and inefficiencies in contract execution.

findings.title: ULTW - Transfers Liquidity to Team Wallet
findings.description: The contract owner has the authority to transfer funds without limit to the marketingWallet. The owner may take advantage of it by calling the swapAndLiquify method.

findings.title: L02 - State Variables could be Declared Constant
findings.description: State variables can be declared as constant using the constant keyword to ensure the value cannot be changed after it has been set, which decreases gas consumption of the corresponding transaction.

findings.title: L04 - Conformance to Solidity Naming Conventions
findings.description: The Solidity style guide is a set of guidelines for writing clean and consistent Solidity code. Adhering to a style guide can help improve the readability and maintainability of the Solidity code, making it easier for others to understand and work with.

findings.title: L05 - Unused State Variable
findings.description: An unused state variable is a state variable that is declared in the contract, but is never used in any of the contract's functions.

findings.title: L09 - Dead Code Elimination
findings.description: Dead code can make a contract more difficult to understand and maintain, and can also increase the size of the contract and the cost of deploying and interacting with it.

findings.title: L14 - Uninitialized Variables in Local Scope
findings.description: Using an uninitialized local variable can lead to unpredictable behavior and potentially cause errors in the contract.

findings.title: L15 - Local Scope Variable Shadowing
findings.description: Local scope variable shadowing occurs when a local variable with the same name as a variable in an outer scope is declared within a function or code block.

findings.title: L17 - Usage of Solidity Assembly
findings.description: Using assembly can be useful for optimizing code, but it can also be error-prone. It's important to carefully test and debug assembly code to ensure that it is correct and does not contain any errors.
